user_message:
<misra_rule>
MISRA C 2023 Rule 8.13 is: A pointer should point to a const-qualified type whenever possible.

</misra_rule>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- is_rule_violated: whether the rule is violated or not (true/false),
- scenario: a specific violation scenario.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of OS_TaskSetPriority:
```c
int32 OS_TaskSetPriority(osal_id_t task_id, osal_priority_t new_priority)
{
    int32                      return_code;
    OS_object_token_t          token;
    OS_task_internal_record_t *task;

    return_code = OS_ObjectIdGetById(OS_LOCK_MODE_GLOBAL, LOCAL_OBJID_TYPE, task_id, &token);
    if (return_code == OS_SUCCESS)
    {
        task = OS_OBJECT_TABLE_GET(OS_task_table, token);

        return_code = OS_TaskSetPriority_Impl(&token, new_priority);

        if (return_code == OS_SUCCESS)
        {
            /* Use the abstracted priority, not the OS one */
            /* Change the priority in the table as well */
            task->priority = new_priority;
        }

        OS_ObjectIdRelease(&token);
    }

    return return_code;
}
```
</target_code>
<target_code>
Here is the code fragment that you need to analyze:
```c
return_code = OS_ObjectIdGetById(OS_LOCK_MODE_GLOBAL, LOCAL_OBJID_TYPE, task_id, &token);
```
Focus on the above code fragment and judge whether it violates the rule 8.13 or not.
</target_code>
scenario: No violation: &token is an output parameter passed to OS_ObjectIdGetById so the function must be able to modify the pointed object; the parameter should therefore be a non-const pointer. Rule 8.13 requires pointers to point to const-qualified types only when the pointed-to object is not modified — a violation would occur only if OS_ObjectIdGetById does not modify the token but still takes a non-const pointer (or if the function prototype could safely use a pointer-to-const but does not).
